content.description: Start on good underclings and left facing sidepulls. Resist a couple strenuous layback moves up the enjoyable and juggy flake system. The rock quality decreases as you ascend, but large sloping holds abound. This would probably be considered a highball.
content.location: Left of The Dead Heart, the first left facing flake holds you see

content.description: Have to imagine someone has climbed this line before, but there was no chalk on it, not in the book, and not on MP. So, here's a great line for you to consider when visiting Outback Boulder. We thought it was harder than the flake to the right and more fun, too.Happy to change name if this is a local line.
content.location: Left of "right V1" in guidebook or "Left Flacing Flake" on Mountain Project is a series of three pocket rails followed by chicken heads. Sit start under that line and go straight up. Taking the direct line should keep you out of the flake to the right.

content.description: Sit start with down pulls and climb up the arête on cool vertical fins and scoops.
content.location: On the overhanging north face. Left arête. To the right are "aborigine" v3/4, and "white fella" v4/5

content.description: Take the obvious path up this right facing flake on some of the best rock on the boulder. Highball, but easy at the top. Fun.
content.location: Just left of the Dead Heart, around the arete

content.description: On the outskirts of the kraft boulder area and a bit secluded. The stand out problem is "the dead heart". Lots of other problems from v0-v5 most of which are still a little sketchy due to soft stone. Almost all problems are a little highball
